title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: R package providing utility functions data pre-processing: viewing unique data entries, fixing Excel decimal symbol errors, data processing tasks.

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: Make minimal, surgical changes fix issues Maintain backward compatibility possible Follow existing patterns codebase Add tests new functionality bug fixes Never leave trailing whitespace end lines blank lines Always add blank line headings bullet points

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: Run devtools::document() update documentation Run devtools::test() testing (use LITE mode faster iteration) Run devtools::check() ensure package passes R CMD check

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: R/ - Source code (use . prefix internal functions) tests/testthat/ - Tests (use helper functions helper-*.R) man/ - Auto-generated docs (edit directly) DESCRIPTION - Package metadata dependencies NAMESPACE - Auto-generated roxygen2 (edit directly) README.Rmd - Source README (edit , README.md) _pkgdown.yml - pkgdown website configuration

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: Use <- assignment (=) Use 2-space indentation Keep lines 80 characters Use clear, descriptive variable names Prefer explicit parameter names function calls
code: # ✅ Correct result <- my_function(data = mtcars, n = 5)  # ❌ Incorrect result = my_function(mtcars, 5)

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: Write vectorized functions possible Include input validation informative error messages Use stop() errors, warning() warnings Handle NA values explicitly Document edge cases
code: #' @title Example function #' @param x numeric vector #' @return numeric vector #' @export #' @examples #' my_function(c(1, 2, 3)) my_function <- function(x) {   if (!is.numeric(x)) stop("x must be numeric")   x * 2 }

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: Use testthat (>= 3.0.0) framework Write tests exported functions Include tests edge cases (NA values, empty inputs) Name test files test-<function-name>.R
code: test_that("my_function handles NA", {   expect_identical(my_function(NA_real_), NA_real_) })

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: Current imports: tibble, magrittr, stringr, dplyr, rlang, purrr adding new dependencies: Add Imports: DESCRIPTION Use package::function() notation code Minimize new dependencies possible

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: Adding New Function: Create R file R/ directory Write function roxygen2 documentation Add @export tag public functions Create test file tests/testthat/ Run devtools::document() update docs Run devtools::check() verify Fixing Bugs: Add failing test reproduces bug Fix bug source code Verify test passes Ensure tests still pass

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: package website built using pkgdown deployed GitHub Pages. IMPORTANT: Always update pkgdown references functions change: adding new exported function, update _pkgdown.yml using custom reference sections removing function, remove _pkgdown.yml reference sections renaming function, update name _pkgdown.yml Run pkgdown::build_site() locally verify site builds correctly pkgdown Configuration: _pkgdown.yml - Main configuration file docs/ - Generated site (.gitignore, commit) .github/workflows/pkgdown.yaml - CI workflow building deploying Updating Reference Organization: _pkgdown.yml contains reference: section custom groupings: Ensure exported functions listed one groups.
code: reference: - title: "Data Viewing"   contents:   - view_unique_col_entries   - view_slice - title: "Data Transformation"   contents:   - fix_excel_decimal_symbol_errors

title: UtilsDataRSV - GitHub Copilot Instructions
text: updating copilot instructions, follow best practices: Keep files 250 lines (max 1000) Use headings, bullets, clear sections direct short, imperative rules Show code examples (correct incorrect patterns) external links (Copilot won’t follow ) vague language like “accurate” Use applyTo frontmatter topic-specific files : ❌ Don’t include external links ❌ Don’t use vague language ❌ Don’t create long dense paragraphs ❌ Don’t try change Copilot’s UX behavior

title: Facilitate data processing
text: UtilsDataRSV R package provides utility functions common data pre-processing tasks. helps streamline workflows offering tools quickly inspect data, fix common import errors, perform group-based data operations.

title: Facilitate data processing
text: Data Inspection: View unique column entries group-based data slices Data Cleaning: Fix Excel decimal symbol errors locale mismatches Data Manipulation: Safe list crossing group-based filtering utilities

title: Facilitate data processing
text: can install UtilsDataRSV GitHub :
code: if (!require("remotes", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("SATVILab/UtilsDataRSV")

title: Facilitate data processing
code: library(UtilsDataRSV)

title: Facilitate data processing
text: view_cols() displays random sample unique entries column dataframe, useful quickly understanding data structure content.

title: Facilitate data processing
text: view_slice() shows subset entries per group, convenient wrapper around dplyr::group_by() dplyr::slice().
code: data("cars") cars[, "grp"] <- rep(letters[1:5], each = 10) view_slice(cars, group = "grp", n_slice = 2) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #> # Groups:   grp [5] #>    speed  dist grp   #>    <dbl> <dbl> <chr> #>  1     4     2 a     #>  2     4    10 a     #>  3    11    28 b     #>  4    12    14 b     #>  5    14    36 c     #>  6    14    60 c     #>  7    17    50 d     #>  8    18    42 d     #>  9    20    52 e     #> 10    20    56 e

title: Facilitate data processing
text: convert_character_to_number_correctly() fixes errors Excel exports numbers using comma decimal separator R expects period.
code: # vector of data (as if from Excel) x <- c("1,32", "1", "0,23", "3,23E-2", NA) x_corrected <- convert_character_to_number_correctly(x = x) # original data alongside corrected data tibble::tibble(original = x, corrected = x_corrected) #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   original corrected #>   <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 1,32        1.32   #> 2 1           1      #> 3 0,23        0.23   #> 4 3,23E-2     0.0323 #> 5 <NA>       NA

title: Facilitate data processing
text: cross_df_safe(): Safely cross lists dataframe, handling multi-length elements without unexpected expansion filter_based_on_mean_grp_value(): Filter data keep groups smallest largest mean value

what: Fix Excel decimal symbol errors — convert_character_to_number_correctly
title: Fix Excel decimal symbol errors — convert_character_to_number_correctly
text: Occasionally numbers read Excel characters R correctly convert characters numbers. function splits number--character integer fraction parts (around whatever decimal indicator present) adds . NOTE: Please check output.

title: Fix Excel decimal symbol errors — convert_character_to_number_correctly
code: convert_character_to_number_correctly(x)

title: Fix Excel decimal symbol errors — convert_character_to_number_correctly
text: x character vector. Column data.

title: Fix Excel decimal symbol errors — convert_character_to_number_correctly
text: function corrects () errors arising importing Excel/CSV file created system uses period (full stop, ie. ".") decimal separator. Note appears entire column read Excel entry number numbers decimal place, readr::read_csv (least) reason read column without comma . function fix .

title: Fix Excel decimal symbol errors — convert_character_to_number_correctly
code: # vector of data (as if from Excel) x <- c("1,32", "1", "0,23", "3,23E-2", NA) x_period <- c("1.32", "1", "0.23", "3.23E-2", NA) # original data alongside corrected data data.frame(orig = x, replacement = convert_character_to_number_correctly(x = x)) #>      orig replacement #> 1    1,32      1.3200 #> 2       1      1.0000 #> 3    0,23      0.2300 #> 4 3,23E-2      0.0323 #> 5    <NA>          NA

title: Safely cross lists — cross_df_safe
text: Returns cartesian elements list dataframe, one combination per row.

title: Safely cross lists — cross_df_safe
code: cross_df_safe(.l, .filter = NULL)

title: Safely cross lists — cross_df_safe
text: .l list lists atomic vectors (, dataframe). .filter function. predicate function takes number arguments number variables combined.

title: Safely cross lists — cross_df_safe
text: dataframe number rows

title: Safely cross lists — cross_df_safe
text: Elements list crossed list(1, 2:3) keep multi-length elements one combination (.e. one dataframe row). sense "safe", behaves expected lists "guarded", .e. joined together. function `purrr::cross` returns error case, whilst `purrr::cross` piped `purrr::map_df(tibble::as_tibble)` w creates two combinations (two dataframe rows) second list element . One wrap second element list, adds extra layer accessing element combination. Another advantage See examples demonstration.

title: Safely cross lists — cross_df_safe
code: # cross_df_safe automatically # "protects" non-list list elements to_cross_list <- list(   V1 = c("a", "b"),   V2 = list(3, 4:5) ) # returns an error try(purrr::cross_df(to_cross_list)) #> Warning: `cross_df()` was deprecated in purrr 1.0.0. #> ℹ Please use `tidyr::expand_grid()` instead. #> ℹ See <https://github.com/tidyverse/purrr/issues/768>. #> Warning: `cross()` was deprecated in purrr 1.0.0. #> ℹ Please use `tidyr::expand_grid()` instead. #> ℹ See <https://github.com/tidyverse/purrr/issues/768>. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the purrr package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/tidyverse/purrr/issues>. #> Error in recycle_columns(x, .rows, lengths) :  #>   Tibble columns must have compatible sizes. #> • Size 4: Column `V1`. #> • Size 6: Column `V2`. #> ℹ Only values of size one are recycled. # can avoid this by wrapping each to-cross # element's elements in lists, # but then the crossed dataframe # has second column's elements # each be lists to_cross_list_list <- list(   V1 = c("a", "b"),   V2 = list(list(3), list(4:5)) ) cross_df_purrr <- purrr::cross_df(to_cross_list_list) cross_df_purrr$V2 #> [[1]] #> [[1]][[1]] #> [1] 3 #>  #>  #> [[2]] #> [[2]][[1]] #> [1] 3 #>  #>  #> [[3]] #> [[3]][[1]] #> [1] 4 5 #>  #>  #> [[4]] #> [[4]][[1]] #> [1] 4 5 #>  #>  # returns a four-row dataframe, where # second column has elements of lengths 1, 1, 2 and 2 # that are not lists cross_df_sf <- cross_df_safe(to_cross_list) cross_df_sf$V2 #> [[1]] #> [1] 3 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 3 #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] 4 5 #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] 4 5 #>  # the above is more natural to work with # no element in a combination # is needlessly wrapped inside an unnamed list of length 1  # to_cross_list_list <- list(   V1 = c(list("a"), list("b")),   V2 = list(     c("a" = "c"),     c("b" = "d")   ) )  cross_df_std <- purrr::cross_df(to_cross_list_list) cross_df_sf <- cross_df_safe(to_cross_list_list) # purr:cross_df needlessly places each element of V2 # (e.g. list("a" = "c")) in its own list: cross_df_std$V2 #>   a   a   b   b  #> "c" "c" "d" "d"  # the above means that to refer to the element, you need to # add an extra set of brackets: # cross_df_std$V2[[1]][[1]] # in this case, however,cross_df_safe flattens the list by one level: cross_df_sf$V2 #> [[1]] #>   a  #> "c"  #>  #> [[2]] #>   a  #> "c"  #>  #> [[3]] #>   b  #> "d"  #>  #> [[4]] #>   b  #> "d"  #>  # so that you can refer to individual elements more succinctly: cross_df_sf$V2[[1]] #>   a  #> "c"

what: Choose subset of data with larger/smaller mean value — filter_based_on_mean_grp_value
title: Choose subset of data with larger/smaller mean value — filter_based_on_mean_grp_value
text: Choose subset data larger/smaller mean value

title: Choose subset of data with larger/smaller mean value — filter_based_on_mean_grp_value
code: filter_based_on_mean_grp_value(data, val, grp_outer, grp_inner, sel)

title: Choose subset of data with larger/smaller mean value — filter_based_on_mean_grp_value
text: data dataframe. Dataframe subset(s) chosen. val character. Name column data containing data whose mean determines group group_inner choose. grp_outer character. Name column data indicating group entries one level grp_inner chosen. grp_inner character. Name column data indicating sub-groups grp_outer. one level grp_inner chosen per level grp_outer. sel 'smaller' 'larger'. Level grp_inner chosen per level grp_outer smallest mean groups (defined grp_inner) level grp_outer, sel == 'smaller'. Opposite sel == 'larger'. default.

title: Choose subset of data with larger/smaller mean value — filter_based_on_mean_grp_value
text: dataframe one level grp_inner level grp_outer.

title: Choose subset of data with larger/smaller mean value — filter_based_on_mean_grp_value
text: written situation abundance various types cells available (e.g. CD4 T cells expressing IFNg+), frequencies counts available indicated column pertains frequencies counts. Note function work reliably response frequency (rather proportion) denominator cell count consistently much higher 100.

title: Choose subset of data with larger/smaller mean value — filter_based_on_mean_grp_value
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(tibble) library(purrr) library(stringr) set.seed(3) test_tbl <- tibble(   pid = rep(c("id1", "id2", "id1", "id2"), each = 2),   type = c(paste0(rep(c("a", "b"), each = 4), rep(c("", "_1"), 4))) ) %>%   mutate(type_base = stringr::str_remove(type, "_1")) %>%   group_by(pid, type_base) %>%   mutate(resp = purrr::map_dbl(type_base, function(x) {     round(rnorm(1, 5 + stringr::str_detect(x, "b") * 3), 2)   })[1]) %>%   ungroup() %>%   mutate(resp = ifelse(str_detect(type, "_1"), rep(runif(4, 1e4, 1e5), each = 2), 1) * resp)  test_tbl #> # A tibble: 8 × 4 #>   pid   type  type_base      resp #>   <chr> <chr> <chr>         <dbl> #> 1 id1   a     a              4.04 #> 2 id1   a_1   a          80923.   #> 3 id2   a     a              5.2  #> 4 id2   a_1   a         381326.   #> 5 id1   b     b              8.26 #> 6 id1   b_1   b         749793.   #> 7 id2   b     b              8.09 #> 8 id2   b_1   b         284573.    filter_based_on_mean_grp_value(   data = test_tbl, val = "resp", grp_outer = "type_base",   grp_inner = "type", sel = "smaller" ) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   pid   type  type_base  resp #>   <chr> <chr> <chr>     <dbl> #> 1 id1   a     a          4.04 #> 2 id2   a     a          5.2  #> 3 id1   b     b          8.26 #> 4 id2   b     b          8.09

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
code: lhs %>% rhs

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling `rhs(lhs)`.

what: View random sample of unique column entries — view_cols
title: View random sample of unique column entries — view_cols
text: Displays n_entry unique entries first n_col columns. Note NA always included amongst displayed entries present.

title: View random sample of unique column entries — view_cols
code: view_cols(x, n_entry = 20, n_entry_num = 5, n_col = 100, silent = FALSE)

title: View random sample of unique column entries — view_cols
text: x dataframe. Dataframe unique column entries displayed. n_entry integer. Maximum unique entries display per column. Set equal Inf want see unique column entries. Default 20. n_entry_num Maximum number unique entries display numeric columns. Set equal Inf want see unique entries. NULL, n_entry used numeric columns well. Default 5. n_col integer. Maximum number columns display unique entries . message default displayed fewer columns data data displayed. Set equal Inf columns displayed. integer still number, integer component number columns displayed.  Default n_col 1e2. silent logical. TRUE, message fewer columns displayed total columns available printed. Default FALSE.

title: View random sample of unique column entries — view_cols

what: Print slices per group of a dataframe — view_slice
title: Print slices per group of a dataframe — view_slice
text: Wrapper around Returns subsetted data invisibly.

title: Print slices per group of a dataframe — view_slice
code: view_slice(   data,   group,   select = NULL,   n_print = 1000,   n_slice = 1,   seed = NULL,   sample_within_group = FALSE,   sample = FALSE,   prop_sample = NULL,   return = FALSE )

title: Print slices per group of a dataframe — view_slice
text: data dataframe. Contains data print. group character. Name column group subsetting. select character vector. Name(s) columns select printing. n_print numeric. Number slices print per group. n_slice numeric. Number slices select per group. seed numeric. NULL, seed set value. Default NULL. sample_within_group logical. TRUE sampling selected, sampling performed within group. Otherwise sampling performed across whole table. Default FALSE. sample logical. TRUE, rows sampled. Unless prop_sample specified, n_slice rows sampled. prop_sample numeric. NULL, proportion rows sample. Overrides n_slice. Default NULL. return logical. TRUE, subsetted table returned. Otherwise, invisible(TRUE) returned. Default FALSE.

title: Print slices per group of a dataframe — view_slice
code: data("cars") cars[, "grp"] <- rep(letters[1:5], each = 10) view_slice(cars, group = "grp", n_slice = 2) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #> # Groups:   grp [5] #>    speed  dist grp   #>    <dbl> <dbl> <chr> #>  1     4     2 a     #>  2     4    10 a     #>  3    11    28 b     #>  4    12    14 b     #>  5    14    36 c     #>  6    14    60 c     #>  7    17    50 d     #>  8    18    42 d     #>  9    20    52 e     #> 10    20    56 e
